official-title.#text:
To require the Secretary of the Treasury to mint coins in
		  commemoration of the centennial of the Panama-Pacific International Exposition
		  and the Panama Canal, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced
			 the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Panama Canal and Pan-Pacific
			 Exhibition Centennial Celebration Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text: The

The Panama Canal,
			 which cuts across the Isthmus of Panama, was built between 1890 and 1914. It
			 was the world’s greatest engineering feat of its time and required a labor
			 force of almost 40,000.

President Theodore
			 Roosevelt, recognizing the value of a canal, led the United States in buying
			 the equipment and concession to build the canal for $40 million, and championed
			 the effort that overcame malaria and immense logistical problems. The Canal
			 opened on August 15, 1914—401 years after Spanish explorer Vasco Nuñez de
			 Balboa first crossed Panama.

Stretching 51
			 miles, the Panama Canal connected the Atlantic Ocean and the Pacific Ocean,
			 saving sailors a dangerous 8,000-mile journey around Cape Horn and through the
			 Straits of Magellan, and cutting in half the time previously required to sail
			 between the oceans.

The 1915
			 Panama-Pacific International Exposition was a world’s fair held in San
			 Francisco, California. The Exposition ran from February 20 until December 4,
			 1915.

The Exposition
			 commemorated the completion of the Panama Canal and the 400th anniversary of
			 the discovery of the Pacific Ocean by Balboa.

quote.#tail:
, and included the silver
			 Panama-Pacific half dollar and four gold coins in denominations of one dollar,
			 2

text.#text:
Congress
			 authorized the United States Mint to issue five different coins dated 1915 in
			 connection with the Panama-Pacific International Exposition. The coins
			 represent a high-water mark for American commemorative coins. Produced at the
			 San Francisco Mint, these were the first United States commemorative coins to
			 bear the motto

fraction.#tail:
dollars, a 50-dollar round coin, and a unique
			 50-dollar octagonal coin.

text.#text:
The octagonal $50
			 gold piece was the largest coin authorized by Congress, and the first minted
			 since 1852 in a shape other than round.

The United States
			 should mark the centennial of this important event in San Francisco and the
			 monumental achievement of the opening of the Panama Canal.

The proceeds from
			 the surcharge on the sale of such commemorative coins will assist in supporting
			 the educational programs of the San Francisco Museum and Historical
			 Society.

Not more than 75,000 $5 coins, which shall—

be octagonal in
			 shape;

weigh 8.359

have a distance

contain 90 percent

Not more than 75,000 $5 coins, which shall—

be round in
			 shape;

weigh 8.359
			 grams;

have a diameter of
			 0.850 inches; and

contain 90 percent
			 gold and 10 percent alloy.

header.#text:

			 dollar gold coins

Not more than 50,000 $1 coins, which shall—

have a diameter of

contain 90 percent

Not more than 250,000 half dollar coins, which

weigh 12.5
			 grams;

have a diameter of

contain .999 fine
			 silver.

The coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender, as
			 provided in

text.#text: For purposes of

The design of the coins minted under this Act should be
			 close likenesses of the five coins issued by the San Francisco Mint at the
			 opening of the Pan-Pacific Exposition.

with respect to
			 the octagonal coin, such coin shall also have an obverse and reverse that
			 depicts, in the eight angles of the vertices, eight stylized dolphins that form
			 an outer circle.

The $5 octagonal gold coins minted under this Act and the
			 $5 round gold coins minted under this Act shall be a close likeness of the
			 octagonal Panama-Pacific Exposition $50 gold coin and the round Panama-Pacific
			 Exposition $50 gold coin, respectively. Such coins—

the

			 a Greek mythological hippocampus seahorse, with a caduceus in her left hand;
			 and

the

header.#text:
Two and one-half
			 dollar gold coins

text.#text:
The two and one-half dollar gold coins minted
			 under this Act shall be a close likeness of the Panama-Pacific Exposition two
			 and one-half dollar gold coin, and—

the
			 obverse shall bear the profile of a man wearing a cap which is intended to
			 depict a laborer who worked on the construction of the Panama Canal; and

the
			 reverse shall bear the image of two dolphins symbolizing the meeting of the two
			 oceans, with the inscriptions

The $1 gold coin minted under this Act shall be a close
			 likeness of the Panama-Pacific Exposition $1 gold coin, and—

with an obverse
			 depicting Columbia scattering flowers from a cornucopia held by a small child
			 towards a sunset on the Golden Gate (prior to the construction of the now
			 famous bridge), which was designed by the Mint’s then-Chief Engraver, Charles
			 Barber; and

with a reverse
			 depicting an eagle resting on the union shield with an oak branch to its left,
			 for stability and strength, and an olive branch to its right, for peace,
			 credited to Barber’s assistant George T. Morgan, designer of the Morgan
			 dollar.
